   Assessment and Plan
   40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of
   acromegaly and possible lymphoma, in ICU after respiratory distress
   leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive bradycardia, in the
   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy and urinary retention.
   Current work-up is considering ALL vs Burkitts.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Respiratory distress on [**7-13**] attributed to his
   respiratory/lactic acidosis with LLL PNA, possible infiltrative
   lymphangitic malignant process in both lungs, in the setting of
   aggressive fluid resuscitation. Patient also has a question of a
   history of COPD with significant smoking history (50+ pack years)
   -Advance ETT 1cm more because cuff appears to be above thoracic inlet
   -Switched from AC mode to pressure support [**5-19**] and well tolerated this
   morning. Given that and ABG as well as patient being more alert on
   increased sedation, work toward weaning the vent today.
   -sedation with fentanyl/midazolam, continue until ready to wean vent.
   -Continue antibiotics for PNA: CTX + Cipro
   -Repeat CXR for ETT placement
   -Repeat ABG today after changing vent settings.
   -f/u blood and sputum cx
   Cardiovascular: Persistent tachycardia to 120s for first couple days of
   admission on telemetry and EKG despite significant volume
   resuscitation. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF and no evidence of heart
   failure. Cardiology recommended metoprolol but this was d/c
ed after an
   episode of serious bradycardia requiring transcutaneous pacing on [**7-13**]
   as well as pressors. Cardiac enzymes not concerning for MI, slight
   elevation in troponin likely secondary to ARF.
   -Follow EKGs
   -Follow cardiology recs if they still would like to follow the patient
   -Avoid beta-blockers
   -Monitor CVP with fluids to a goal of [**10-26**] to protect his kidneys.
   -If becomes hypotensive and tachycardic, first choice pressor would be
   phenylephrine.
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia. All
   trending down with IVF and single dose of rasbiricase. CT c/w
   lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process and patient also with
   concerning thickening in stomach, ureters, and possible mass at bottom
   of thoracic spine per MRI.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs (bone marrow biopsy pending, current thinking is ALL
   versus Burkitt
s. challenging review in setting of steroid
   administration) and discuss chemotherapy plans
   -trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) Q8H
   -start allopurinol given normalized Cr
   -repeat dose of rasbiracase 6mg x 1
   -EBV results
   -SPEP results
   -continue hydration
   -guaiac stools (Hct trending down since admission)
   Renal/FEN: Creatinine went from 0.6 at admission to max of 1.6,
   currently 0.8. ARF was attributed to ATN in the setting of high uric
   acid levels to 12 range.  Patient
s initial presentation was also
   urinary retention. U/S at OSH was reportedly normal. CT shows
   urothelial thickening and prostate may also be enlarged in the setting
   of acromegaly.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -continue fluids to CVP 10-12
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds until Cr stabilized
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed.
   Endocrine: Per OSH records, he had an MRI/MRA head [**7-11**] which revealed
   a 19 x30x 15mm pituitary macroadenoma which had some invasion of left
   cavernous sinus. Acromegaly suspected and could help explain appearance
   and intial complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and
   urinary retention. Endocrinology consult called and patient has had
   normal TSH, low testosterone, LH elevated, slightly high cortisol
   levels. Prolactin is normal. PTH is normal. High [**Hospital1 **] at 11.2 and IGF was
   188.
   - f/u endocrine recs  (do they still want the following labs: free
   IGF-1(lab can instruct how to do this), IGFBP, repeat [**Hospital1 **], possible OGTT
   with [**Hospital1 **] levels 2hrs post 75g load, pituitary MRI, Vit D labs, UPEP
   - call for full opthalmology consult once alert and awake for thorough
   visual field tests
   -When stabilized, consider repeat Ca and PTH drawn at same time (PTH
   was normal in setting of high Ca)
   Neuro: MRI T-spine done and showed no overt compressions, but diffuse
   nerve root enhancement of lumbar spine and epidural signal changes at
   T9, T12, L2. Most likely from his overall infiltrative
   process/malignancy. Thoracic epidural enhancement on MRA, MRI
   concerning for possible masses.  Neurosurgery team is  following.
   Patient already on dexamethasone for malignancy treatment. No reported
   incontinence, only retention of urine but may be due to enlarged
   prostate from acromegaly vs additional obstruction at the level of
   ureter as imaging noted thickening of urothelial linings ( likely also
   related to underlying malignancy). Patient also initially presented
   with a Bell
s palsy, possibly related to acromegaly.
   -f/u with neurosurgery regarding T-spine mass and MRI of lumbar spine
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII
   -continue acyclovir
   ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc and CTX.
   Patient also on Cipro for question of STI orchitis.
   -consider HIV test in setting of possible aggressive lymphoma
   -f/u EBV PCR
   -HIV test when patient alert and able to consent
   -d/c cipro
   -continue vanc and CTX for hospital-acquired PNA
   GU:  Initial complaint was urinary retention. Possibly secondary to
   enlarged prostate from acromegaly and/or urothelial thickening on CT.
   Tender scrotal swelling also noted on admission and scrotal US
   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C
   swab was negative. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to anasarca and malignancy work-up.
   Hcg and AFP negative.
   -Foley in place
   -Closely monitor UOP given recent h/o retention.
   MSK: Patient complained of diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary
   to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly, possible infiltrative
   process.
   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake
   -continue pain control with fentanyl

The patient is a 40-year-old male with a chief complaint of tumor lysis syndrome. He is being worked up for acromegaly and possible lymphoma. The patient is currently in the ICU after experiencing respiratory distress, which led to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia. He also has pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. The patient's medical history includes Bell's Palsy and urinary retention.

24-hour events:
- The patient was extubated at 4pm but required reintubation at 11pm due to tachypnea and increased work of breathing.
- Tumor lysis labs improved, and the patient received another dose of rasburicase, followed by a transition to allopurinol as per hematology-oncology recommendations.
- A peripheral blood sample was sent for flow cytometry because necrosis of the bone marrow rendered the biopsy inadequate for results.

Assessment and plan:
- The patient has respiratory distress attributed to his respiratory/lactic acidosis with left lower lobe pneumonia, possible infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process in both lungs, and aggressive fluid resuscitation.
- The patient's cardiovascular status is characterized by persistent tachycardia despite significant volume resuscitation. Cardiology recommended metoprolol but was discontinued after an episode of serious bradycardia requiring transcutaneous pacing.    40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of
   acromegaly and possible lymphoma, in ICU after respiratory distress
   leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive bradycardia, in the
   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy and urinary retention.
   Current work-up is considering ALL vs Burkitts.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Extubated and reintubated yesterday due to tachypnea and
   increased difficulty breathing secondary to copious secretions. Being
   treated for LLL PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant
   process based on chest CT
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
   -Repeat CXR tomorrow morning
   -Get better COPD history from friend
   -Continue [**Name2 (NI) 114**]
   -Get ABG if change in respiratory status or if change ventilator
   settings
   -f/u blood cx
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure.
   -Continue volume resuscitation to goal CVP of [**10-26**].
   -EKG
   -Avoid beta blockers given h/o hypotension on metoprolol
   -guaiac stool
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, flow
   cytometry of peripheral blood now pending with high suspicion for an
   acute lymphoma. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
   -continue allopurinol
   -EBV antibodies pending; consider sending PCR if suspicion is high
   given his hypogammaglobulinemia on SPEP
   -continue hydration
   -Today is Day 4 of dexamethasone. Tomorrow start brief taper.
   -daily differential
   -BAL flow cytometry pending
   -touch base with neurosurgery to see if CT guided biopsy of spinal mass
   is possible
   Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving with Cre back at baseline of 0.5.
   Patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention has not been an issue. This
   will need to be monitored when Foley is eventually removed.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -continue fluids to CVP 10-12
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now.
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly; MRI/MRA shows pituitary
   macroadenoma (presumptive source). This may help explain initial
   complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention
   although follow-up for these complaints will be required when patient
   is extubated and stabilized. Only endocrine lab abnormalities to date
   are an elevated [**Hospital1 **] and LH and a low testosterone. Interestingly, IGF-1
   was normal, although this is not reliable in acute illness. Free IGF-1
   level requested by endocrine was not possible at our lab. Repeat Ca and
   PTH were both normal, eliminating suspicion for parathyroid process.
   -f/u endocrine consult

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 40-year-old male with a chief complaint of tumor lysis syndrome.
- He is being worked up for acromegaly and possible lymphoma.
- The patient was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory distress, leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia.
- He has a history of Bell's palsy and urinary retention.
- The patient has been treated for lower lobe pneumonia and suspected infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT.
- He has tachycardia and a history of heart failure, but an EKG shows no evidence of heart failure.
- The patient's labs indicate significantly elevated LDH, hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia consistent with tumor lysis syndrome.
- He has received two doses of rasburicase and is now on allopurinol.
- The patient has a bone marrow biopsy that is inadequate due to necrosis, and flow cytometry of peripheral blood is pending.
- CT shows evidence of malignancy with lymphangitic spread and thickening in the stomach and ureters.
- The patient has acute lymphocytic leukemia versus Burkitt's lymphoma under consideration.
- He is currently extubated but may need to be reintubated due to tachypnea and increased work of breathing.
- The patient has renal failure that is resolving, and

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of
   acromegaly and possible lymphoma, in ICU after respiratory distress
   leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive bradycardia, in the
   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy and urinary retention.
   Current work-up is considering ALL vs Burkitts.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Extubated and reintubated yesterday due to tachypnea and
   increased difficulty breathing secondary to copious secretions. Being
   treated for LLL PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant
   process based on chest CT
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
   -Repeat CXR tomorrow morning
   -Get better COPD history from friend
   -Continue [**Name2 (NI) 114**]
   -Get ABG if change in respiratory status or if change ventilator
   settings
   -f/u blood cx
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure.
   -Continue volume resuscitation to goal CVP of [**10-26**].
   -EKG
   -Avoid beta blockers given h/o hypotension on metoprolol
   -guaiac stool
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, flow
   cytometry of peripheral blood now pending with high suspicion for an
   acute lymphoma. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
   -continue allopurinol
   -EBV antibodies pending; consider sending PCR if suspicion is high
   given his hypogammaglobulinemia on SPEP
   -continue hydration
   -Today is Day 4 of dexamethasone. Tomorrow start brief taper.
   -daily differential
   -BAL flow cytometry pending
   -touch base with neurosurgery to see if CT guided biopsy of spinal mass
   is possible
   Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving with Cre back at baseline of 0.5.
   Patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention has not been an issue. This
   will need to be monitored when Foley is eventually removed.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -continue fluids to CVP 10-12
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now.
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly; MRI/MRA shows pituitary
   macroadenoma (presumptive source). This may help explain initial
   complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention
   although follow-up for these complaints will be required when patient
   is extubated and stabilized. Only endocrine lab abnormalities to date
   are an elevated [**Hospital1 **] and LH and a low testosterone. Interestingly, IGF-1
   was normal, although this is not reliable in acute illness. Free IGF-1
   level requested by endocrine was not possible at our lab. Repeat Ca and

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 40-year-old male with a history of tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for acromegaly and possible lymphoma. He is currently in the ICU after experiencing respiratory distress, leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia. The patient has been treated for left lower lobe pneumonia and has shown improvement. His renal function has also improved, but he still requires ongoing medical management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Complications: The patient's initial presentation included respiratory distress and subsequent intubation. There is a risk of further respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or worsening of the underlying pneumonia.

2. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's tachycardia and history of hypotension on metoprolol indicate potential cardiovascular issues. Close monitoring of the patient's cardiovascular status is necessary to prevent complications like arrhythmias or heart failure.

3. Renal Complications: The patient initially presented with acute kidney injury (ARF), which has shown improvement. However, ongoing monitoring of renal function is essential to prevent further renal complications.

4. Endocrine Complications: The patient has a new diagnosis of acromegaly, which may explain his initial complaints of cranial nerve palsies, lower extremity weakness, and urinary retention. Close follow-up and management by endocrinology will be required.

 persistent, possible underlying systemic process (such as
   symptoms from maligancy) or infection (ex. Pneumonia).  Unrevealing
   imaging.  Cultures pending.  Monitor fevers, use coolig blanket.
   Continue empiric antimicrobials (Vanco, ceftriaxone, Ciprofloxicin)
   ABN BONE MARROW -- biopsy unrevealing for specific diagnosis.  Necrosis
   and many small cells of unclear etiology.  Next plan for peripherlal
   blood sample for flow cytometry analysis.  Will also send bronchoscopy
   BAL for flow cytometry.  Consider repeat Bone Marrow Bx.
   TACHYCARDIA -- consistent with sinus tachycardia with APCs.  Monitor.
   HYPOTENSION
 concern for sepsis and component of hypovolemia.  No
   evidence for adrenal insufficiency.  Improved, and now off
   vasopressors.   Maintain = CVP 10-12 cm H2O.
   FLUIDS
 need to further assess intravascular status.  [**Month (only) 11**] require iv
   fluid bolus to maintain.  Follow CVP= 10-12 cm H2O.
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE -- Improving following resuscitation.  Attributed
   to ATN, possible tumor lysis syndrome, bilateral obstruction, drug
   effect.  Creatinine now at baseline.
   TUMOR LYSIS SYNDROME
  unclear etiology.  Continue Rasburicase,
   Allopurinol.  Trend electrolytes q8 hrs.  Oncology preliminary
   impression favors ALL/AML
 bone marrow results pending.  Continue
   dexamethasone.
   ACROMEGALLY
 Reportedly with evidnece for Pituitary adenoma.
   Evaluation in progresss.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 initiate TF if no plans for procedures.

Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure. The patient was extubated yesterday but developed copious oral secretions and poor handling of cough, leading to declining SaO2. The patient was re-intubated and remains intubated and mechanically ventilated. The patient has a history of tobacco abuse and has shown signs of pneumonia, diffuse bronchovascular disease, lymphangitic engorgement, and possible underlying COPD. The patient's fever persists, and cultures are pending. The patient also has abnormal bone marrow findings, sinus tachycardia with APCs, hypotension, acute renal failure, and possible tumor lysis syndrome. The patient's condition requires close monitoring, and multiple interventions are being implemented to manage their various complications. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure due to pneumonia, diffuse bronchovascular disease, and possible underlying COPD.
2. Fever indicating a possible underlying systemic process or infection.
3. Abnormal bone marrow findings, which may indicate a hematological malignancy such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) or acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
4. Sinus tachycardia with APCs, which may indicate cardiac involvement or arrhythmia.
5. Hypotension, possibly due to sepsis and hypovolemia.
6. Acute renal failure, potentially attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), tumor lysis syndrome

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male with a history of tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of acromegaly and possible lymphoma. The patient was admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Respiratory: Extubated and reintubated yesterday due to tachypnea and increased difficulty breathing secondary to copious secretions. Being treated for LLL PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT.
- Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF and no evidence of heart failure.
- Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH, hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses rasburicase. Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, flow cytometry of peripheral blood now pending with high suspicion for an acute lymphoma. CT also shows evidence of malignancy c/w lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
- Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving with

   40M with resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new
   diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in ICU after
   respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive
   bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic
   acidosis. Original presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary
   retention, and lower extremity weakness.
   Currently trying to obtain tissue for definitive lymphoma diagnosis
   from BAL, peripheral blood, and paraspinal mass.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Intubated, on assist control mode for past 36 hours after
   failed extubation secondary to copious secretions. Being treated for
   PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on
   chest CT.
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with propofol/fentanyl/midazolam
   -Wean to pressure support as tolerated.
   -Daily CXR
   -Obtain better COPD history
   -Continue abx for 2 more days (7 day total)
   -Continue ABG twice daily from art line or if changes in respiratory
   status
   -f/u blood cx
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure. EKG yesterday showed frequent PVCs,
   no signs of myocardial ischemia.
   -Start metoprolol 25mg PO TID and titrate as needed.
   -f/u other cardiology recs
   -transfuse if Hct<21
   -guaiac stool
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
   Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, now trying to
   obtain diagnosis from alternate tissue.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
   -continue allopurinol
   -d/c dexamethasone today
   -daily differential
   -BAL flow cytometry and cytology pending
   -biopsy of paraspinal mass not possible per IR. Plan to repeat bone
   marrow bx on monday
   Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving with Cre back at baseline of 0.5.
   Patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention has not been an issue. This
   will need to be monitored when Foley is eventually removed.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -d/c IVF, start again if CVP<8
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly; MRI/MRA shows pituitary
   macroadenoma (presumptive source). This may help explain initial
   complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention
   although follow-up for these complaints will be required when patient
   is extubated and stabilized. Only endocrine lab abnormalities to date
   are an elevated [**Hospital1 **] and LH and a low testosterone. Interestingly, IGF-1
   was normal, although this is not reliable in acute illness. Free IGF-1
   level requested by endocrine was not possible at our lab. Repeat Ca and
   PTH were both normal, eliminating suspicion for parathyroid process.
   -f/u endocrine recs
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -consider OGTT in future
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for
   possible masses.
   -IR to biopsy paraspinal mass
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc (since [**7-13**])
   and CTX (since [**7-14**]). ID approval was received for vanc. CXR on [**7-15**]
   newly concerning for aspiration.
   -Continue abx for hospital-acquired PNA. Day 5 vancomycin, Day 4 CTX.
   Continue to day 7.
   -Add gram-negative coverage for suspected aspiration PNA.
   -urine cx negative; sputum cx grew yeast; blood cx from [**7-13**] pending
   -HIV test when patient alert and able to consent
   -EBV IgG negative, IgM and PCR pending
   -Legionella negative
   - negative ADENO,PARAINFLUENZA 1,2,3 INFLUENZA A,B AND, RSV
   GU:  Initial complaint was urinary retention. Possibly secondary to
   enlarged prostate from acromegaly and/or urothelial thickening on CT.
   Tender scrotal swelling also noted on admission and scrotal US
   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C
   swab was negative. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to anasarca and malignancy work-up.
   -Foley in place
   -When patient extubated/stabilized and Foley removed, close follow-up
   will be needed for h/o urinary retention as well as presumptive
   diagnosis of orchitis. No treatment currently given negative G&C swab.
   -Monitor UOP
   MSK: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary
   to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.
   -avoiding NSAIDs

Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:
- The patient is a 40-year-old male with a history of tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for possible lymphoma and acromegaly.
- He was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory distress, leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia.
- The patient has been treated for pneumonia and is currently on assisted ventilation.
- His vital signs include a temperature of 38.1°C (100.6°F), heart rate of 116 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 147/64-83 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%.
- The patient has a prominent frontal bossing, maxillary/mandibular protrusion, and large coarse facial features.
- Physical examination also reveals fullness of the thyroid gland, decreased bowel sounds, soft abdomen, prominent and enlarged hands/feet, edematous lower extremities, and limited neurologic examination.
- Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelets, and LDH levels, as well as hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia, and elevated troponin-T level.
- Imaging studies show evidence of malignancy with lymphangitic spread, thickening in the stomach, and ureters.
- The patient is currently on various medications, including propofol, fentanyl, midazolam

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 40-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress. He has a history of tumor lysis syndrome, suspected lymphoma, and acromegaly. The patient is currently intubated and on assist control mode ventilation due to failed extubation secondary to copious secretions. He has been treated for pneumonia and there is suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT.

The patient's cardiovascular status is tachycardic with a heart rate in the 110s/120s. TSH levels are within normal range and a TTE showed normal ejection fraction and no evidence of heart failure. Frequent PVCs were noted on the EKG, but no signs of myocardial ischemia were present.

The patient's renal function is improving, with creatinine levels returning to baseline. He has a Foley catheter in place for urinary retention, which has not been an issue since the catheter was inserted. Electrolyte abnormalities are improving, with repletion as needed.

Endocrine labs show elevated LH and a low testosterone, along with an elevated [**Hospital1 **] level. IGF-1 was normal, but repeat Ca and PTH were both normal, ruling out parathyroid process. The patient has a new diagnosis of acromegaly, with an MRI/MRA showing a pituitary macroadenoma.

Neurological examination is limited secondary to sed

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new
   diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in ICU after
   respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive
   bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic
   acidosis. Original presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary
   retention, and lower extremity weakness.
   Currently trying to obtain tissue for definitive lymphoma diagnosis
   from BAL, peripheral blood, and paraspinal mass.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Intubated, on assist control mode for past 36 hours after
   failed extubation secondary to copious secretions. Being treated for
   PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on
   chest CT.
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with propofol/fentanyl/midazolam
   -Wean to pressure support as tolerated.
   -Daily CXR
   -Obtain better COPD history
   -Continue abx for 2 more days (7 day total)
   -Continue ABG twice daily from art line or if changes in respiratory
   status
   -f/u blood cx
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure. EKG yesterday showed frequent PVCs,
   no signs of myocardial ischemia.
   -Start metoprolol 25mg PO TID and titrate as needed.
   -f/u other cardiology recs
   -transfuse if Hct<21
   -guaiac stool
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
   Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, now trying to
   obtain diagnosis from alternate tissue.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
   -continue allopurinol
   -d/c dexamethasone today
   -daily differential
   -BAL flow cytometry and cytology pending
   -biopsy of paraspinal mass not possible per IR. Plan to repeat bone
   marrow bx on monday
   Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving with Cre back at baseline of 0.5.
   Patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention has not been an issue. This
   will need to be monitored when Foley is eventually removed.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -d/c IVF, start again if CVP<8
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly; MRI/MRA shows pituitary
   macroadenoma (presumptive source). This may help explain initial
   complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention
   although follow-up for these complaints will be required when patient
   is extubated and stabilized. Only endocrine lab abnormalities to date
   are an elevated [**Hospital1 **] and LH and a low testosterone. Interestingly, IGF-1
   was normal, although this is not reliable in acute illness. Free IGF-1
   level requested by endocrine was not possible at our lab. Repeat Ca and
   PTH were both normal, eliminating suspicion for parathyroid process.
   -f/u endocrine recs
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -consider OGTT in future
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for
   possible masses.
   -IR to biopsy paraspinal mass
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc (since [**7-13**])
   and CTX (since [**7-14**]). ID approval was received for vanc. CXR on [**7-15**]
   newly concerning for aspiration.
   -Continue abx for hospital-acquired PNA. Day 5 vancomycin, Day 4 CTX.
   Continue to day 7.
   -Add gram-negative coverage for suspected aspiration PNA.
   -urine cx negative; sputum cx grew yeast; blood cx from [**7-13**] pending
   -HIV test when patient alert and able to consent
   -EBV IgG negative, IgM and PCR pending
   -Legionella negative
   - negative ADENO,PARAINFLUENZA 1,2,3 INFLUENZA A,B AND, RSV
   GU:  Initial complaint was urinary retention. Possibly secondary to

   Tender scrotal swelling also noted on admission and scrotal US
   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C

   -Foley in place
   -When patient extubated/stabilized and Foley removed, close follow-up

Summary:
The patient is a 40-year-old male with a history of resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in the ICU after respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. The patient initially presented with Bell's Palsy, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness.

The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a Vt set at 650 mL and RR set at 22. The FiO2 is 50% and PEEP is 5 cmH2O. The ABG results show a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 244, indicating good oxygenation. The physical examination reveals diffuse wheezing on the left side, decreased bowel sounds, and edematous lower extremities.

The lab results show a WBC count of 5.5, Hct of 27%, Plt of 140,000/mm3, and LDH of 3020 IU/L. The electrolyte levels are within normal limits. The imaging studies show evidence of mild pulmonary vasc congestion, new parenchymal opacity at the left lung apex, and worsening opacity at the right lung base. The CXR also shows a small right pleural effusion.

The assessment and plan include respiratory support, cardiovascular monitoring, heme-oncological workup, renal monitoring, endocrine

Summary:
Based on the provided information, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient:

1. Respiratory Complications:
   - Pneumonia: The patient is being treated for left lower lobe pneumonia, which indicates an active infection in the lungs. This can lead to worsening respiratory symptoms and increased risk of respiratory failure.
   - Respiratory distress: The patient initially experienced respiratory distress leading to intubation. This could be due to various factors such as lung infection, pulmonary edema, or respiratory muscle weakness.
   - Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): As the patient is on mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP, which is a type of lung infection acquired during hospitalization.

2. Cardiovascular Complications:
   - Tachycardia: The patient has been consistently tachycardic with a heart rate in the range of 110-120 beats per minute. This may be due to fever, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
   - Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotensive bradycardia, which could be related to septic shock or medication effects.
   - Cardiac tamponade: Although not explicitly mentioned, the presence of significant respiratory variation in heart rhythm suggests the possibility of cardiac tamponade, especially considering the patient's history of malignancy.

3. Hematologic Complications:
   - Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS): The patient is already experiencing

Mechanical ventilation is being used to assist breathing, and monitoring ABG levels is important to maintain pH within the normal range and ensure adequate oxygenation.

2. Fever: The patient has an elevated temperature, which could be due to an underlying infection, such as pneumonia or lymphoma. Empiric antimicrobials (Vanco, ceftriaxone) are being continued, and a repeat bone marrow biopsy is planned to investigate the possibility of lymphoma.

3. Tachycardia: The patient is experiencing a rapid heart rate consistent with sinus tachycardia with APCs. Metoprolol will be restarted to manage this condition.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications. The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been re-intubated due to difficulty handling copious oral secretions and possible aspiration pneumonia. They also have diffuse bronchovascular disease with lymphangitic engorgement, and underlying COPD is suspected. Monitoring ABG, maintaining pH 7.35-7.40, pO2 >60 mmHg, and continuing antimicrobials are recommended.

2. FEVERS: The patient has persistent fevers, which could be due to an underlying systemic process or infection such as pneumonia. Cultures are pending, and it is advised to monitor fevers and use cooling blankets. Empiric antimicrobials (Vanco, ceftriaxone, Ciprofloxacin) should be continued.

3. ABN BONE MARROW: The patient's bone marrow biopsy was unrevealing for a specific diagnosis, showing necrosis and many small cells of unclear etiology. A peripheral blood sample for flow cytometry analysis and bronchoscopy BAL for flow cytometry are planned. A repeat bone marrow biopsy may also be considered.

4. TACHYCARDIA: The patient has sinus tachycardia with APCs (atrial premature contractions). Monitoring is recommended.

5. HYPOTENSION: The patient has concern for sepsis

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU and potential medical complications that can arise:

Summary:
- The patient underwent a bronchoscopy and sputum culture.
- Vital signs show fever, tachycardia, and slightly elevated blood pressure.
- The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O.
- Physical examination reveals acromegaly, neck supple, distant breath sounds in the lungs, and heart tachy.
- Lab results indicate leukocytosis with a WBC count of 5.5-5.8 K/uL, normal hemoglobin levels, and slightly elevated creatinine and lactic acid levels.
- The patient has a history of tobacco abuse and enlarged lung fields.
- The patient is intubated and sedated, but following simple commands.
- The patient has a known allergy to ciprofloxacin.
- The patient received antibiotics including vancomycin and ceftriaxone.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure due to multifactorial causes such as handling copious oral secretions, pneumonia, diffuse bronchovascular disease with lymphangitic engorgement, and possible underlying COPD. Close monitoring of ABG values and maintaining pH 7.35-7.40 and pO2 >60 mmHg is necessary. Continuing antimicrobials is important.
2. Fevers: The patient has fevers likely due to lymphoma or pneumonia. Repeat BMBx in 3 days, along with continuing empiric antimicrobials (Vanco, ceftriaxone), is advised.
3. Abnormal Bone Marrow: The patient has an abnormal bone marrow biopsy suggesting lymphoma. Repeat Bone Marrow Bx in 3 days and stopping steroids are recommended.
4. Tachycardia: The patient has sinus tachycardia with APCs. Restarting metoprolol is necessary.
5. Tumor Lysis Syndrome: The patient is at risk for tumor lysis syndrome, which is likely related to lymphoma. Close monitoring of labs is advised.
6. Acromegaly: The patient has acromegaly, possibly with evidence of a pituitary adenoma and elevated HGH levels. Further evaluation and management are needed.

Please note that this summary and potential complications are based on the information provided in the progress note. Additional information may be required for a more comprehensive assessment.

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new
   diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in ICU after
   respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive
   bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic
   acidosis. Original presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary
   retention, and lower extremity weakness.
   Currently trying to obtain tissue for definitive lymphoma diagnosis
   from BAL, peripheral blood, and paraspinal mass.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Intubated, on assist control s/p 1 failed extubation
   secondary to copious secretions. Has continued to fail daily breathing
   trial. Being treated for PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic
   malignant process based on chest CT.
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with propofol/fentanyl/midazolam
   -Wean to pressure support as tolerated
   -Daily CXR
   -Consider expanding antibiotic regimen to vanc/zosyn plus flagyl for
   anaerobes due to possibility of aspiration and opacity in RLL that is
   not resolving
   -Continue ABG twice daily from art line or if changes in respiratory
   status
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure. Repeat EKGs have showed no signs of
   myocardial ischemia. Remains tachycardic despite fluid boluses,
   addition of metoprolol, one transfusion. Urine Na 23meq/L suggesting
   absence of hypovolemia.
   -Continue metoprolol 37.5mg TID and titrate up as needed
   -Monitor UOP (currently 30-90mL/hr) and bolus as needed
   -f/u other cardiology recs
   -transfuse again if Hct<21
   -guaiac stool
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
   Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, now trying to
   obtain diagnosis from alternate tissue.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
   -continue allopurinol
   -daily differential
   -repeat bone marrow bx on Monday
   -f/u cytogenetics labs (Bcr-abl and FISH for 9,22 translocation)
   Renal/FEN: Cre at baseline. Patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention
   has not been an issue. This will need to be monitored when Foley is
   eventually removed. UOP 25-90 cc/hr
   -hypernatremia likely secondary to dehydration
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -bolus IVF as needed
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly. Per endocrine, further work-up
   is of no additional value during acute illness. Labs and confirmation
   of dx as well as additional imaging can be obtained when patient is
   stabilized.
   -f/u endocrine recs
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -consider OGTT in future
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for
   possible masses.
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc (since [**7-13**])
   and CTX (since [**7-14**]). ID approval was received for vanc. CXR on [**7-15**]
   newly concerning for aspiration.
   -On abx for hospital-acquired PNA. Day 6 vancomycin, Day 5 CTX.
   Consider expanding regimen and duration.
   -Add gram-negative coverage for suspected aspiration PNA.
   -Repeat blood cx with spikes
   -urine cx negative; sputum cx grew yeast; blood cx from [**7-13**] pending
   -HIV test when patient alert and able to consent
   -EBV IgG negative, IgM and PCR pending
   GU:  Tender scrotal swelling noted on admission and scrotal US
   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C
   swab was negative. Exam today shows marked increase in testicular
   swelling, especially on the left.
   -f/u urinary retention and orchitis when patient stabilized. Orchitis
   likely secondary to infiltration.
   MSK: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary
   to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.
   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake
   -continue pain control with fentanyl

The patient is currently intubated and on assist control ventilation due to failed extubation secondary to copious secretions. He continues to fail daily breathing trials. He is being treated for pneumonia, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT.

The patient's vital signs show tachycardia with a heart rate of 123 bpm, hypertension with a blood pressure of 167/76 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 91% on 50% FiO2. 

The patient's physical examination reveals prominent facial features, wasting in the temporal regions, supple neck, and no lymphadenopathy. The patient has a barrel-shaped chest, regular heart rhythm with distant heart sounds, and diffuse wheezing on the left side. The patient also has decreased bowel sounds, soft and non-distended abdomen, and enlarged hands and feet with edematous lower extremities. The patient's neurologic examination is limited due to sedation, but he moves both arms and legs spontaneously.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, leukocyte count, platelet count, and albumin levels. The patient has deranged electrolyte levels including high potassium, low sodium, and magnesium. The patient's renal function tests indicate acute renal failure with elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels. Other laboratory abnormalities include elevated liver enzymes, lactate, and lactate dehydrogenase levels.

The patient is a 69-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure due to multifactorial causes including pneumonia, diffuse bronchovascular disease, and possible underlying COPD. The patient was intubated again for difficulty handling copious oral secretions. There is a suspicion of lymphoma based on abnormal bone marrow biopsy results. The patient also has sinus tachycardia with APCs and is on metoprolol. There are concerns about tumor lysis syndrome, acromegaly, and scrotal swelling. The patient's anemia needs to be monitored, and ICU care includes repletion with fiber, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcers, and VAP.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including pneumonia, bronchovascular disease, and possible underlying COPD. Continuous monitoring of ABG and maintaining pH 7.35-7.40, pO2 >60 mmHg is necessary. Mechanical ventilation may be required.
2. Fever: The patient has a fever likely due to lymphoma and possible pneumonia. Empiric antimicrobials (Vancomycin and ceftriaxone) should be continued, and repeat BMBx in 2 days is suggested.

Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to multifactorial causes including copious oral secretions, pneumonia, bronchovascular disease, and possible underlying COPD. The patient underwent re-intubation and is currently on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 127 bpm, blood pressure of 131/55 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's recent events include conversion to PSV, increased dose of metoprolol, and transfusion of packed red blood cells.

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including difficulty handling copious oral secretions, pneumonia, diffuse bronchovascular disease with lymphangitic engorgement, and possible underlying COPD. The patient requires close monitoring of ABG, maintenance of pH 7.35-7.40, and pO2 >60 mmHg. Empiric antimicrobials should be continued, and the healthcare team hopes to work towards a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and extubation trial.
2. FEVERS: The patient has a fever likely due to lymphoma or pneumonia. Repeat bone marrow biopsy in 2 days is suggested, along with continuing empiric antimicrobials

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an intubated and sedated individual in the ICU. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.8 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 127 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 107/44 mmHg to 187/76 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's weight is currently 79.1 kg, and height is 69 inches. The central venous pressure (CVP) is 6 mmHg, and fluid balance shows an intake of 4,320 mL with 1,919 mL coming from IV fluids, 950 mL from tube feeding, and 507 mL from peripheral IV fluids. Output includes 1,210 mL of urine, 395 mL of blood products, and 1,524 mL of drain fluid. The patient's respiratory support consists of an endotracheal tube with CPAP/PSV ventilation mode, set tidal volume (Vt) of 650 mL, respiratory rate (RR) of 22 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results are within normal limits, indicating a pH of 7.41, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 46 mmHg, oxygen saturation (SaO2) of 96%, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 202 mmHg. The patient's laboratory results show hemoglobin (Hb) of 8.8 g/dL, white blood cell count (WBC) of 5.5 K/uL, platelet count (Plt) of 140 K/uL, blood glucose of 112 mg/dL, and creatinine (Cr) level of 0.5 mg/dL. The patient's medication regimen includes metoprolol, midazolam, propofol, heparin sodium, famotidine, and various other medications. The patient's code status is full code, and their disposition is unknown.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory status and appropriate antibiotic therapy will be crucial.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE): Immobility and central venous catheterization increase the risk of DVT, which can lead to PE. Prophylactic measures such as compression stockings and heparin should be considered.
3. Nosocomial infection: Prolonged ICU stay and invasive procedures increase the risk of nosocomial infections, including catheter-related bloodstream infections. Regular assessment of vital signs and laboratory parameters

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical conditions and complications. Here is a summary of the information:

- The patient has respiratory failure due to a combination of factors including pneumonia, diffuse bronchovascular disease, lymphangitic engorgement, and possible underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient is being mechanically ventilated and will be monitored for ABG results to maintain pH between 7.35-7.40 and pO2 above 60 mmHg. Antimicrobials will continue, and the healthcare team hopes to perform a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and consider extubation soon.

- The patient also has fevers, likely caused by lymphoma or pneumonia. Empiric antimicrobials (Vancomycin and ceftriaxone) will continue, and a repeat bone marrow biopsy is planned in three days to confirm the presence of lymphoma. Steroids will be stopped.

- The patient has tachycardia, specifically sinus tachycardia with atrial premature complexes (APCs). Metoprolol will be restarted to manage the heart rate.

- There are concerns about tumor lysis syndrome, which is likely related to lymphoma. Lab results have improved.

- The patient reportedly has acromegaly, possibly due to a pituitary adenoma with elevated growth hormone levels.

In terms of ICU care, the patient is receiving nutrition

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with recent tumor lysis syndrome. He is being worked up for new diagnoses of acromegaly and B cell lymphoma. The patient experienced respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia in the setting of pneumonia and lactic acidosis.

The patient received 1 unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs), NS bolus, and 500 cc NS bolus for decreased urine output and cardiac recommendations. His metoprolol dosage was increased to 37.5mg TID. The patient had a conversation with family members and failed rota caps (RISB) in the morning but did well on propofol sedation, showing labored breathing and anxiety once more sedation was lightened. Secretions were mostly above the cuff.

The patient's allergies are listed as no known drug allergies. Antibiotics administered include ceftriaxone and vancomycin on 07/18/2144 at 03:45 AM and 09:00 AM, respectively. The patient is currently receiving infusions of fentanyl, propofol, and midazolam (Versed). Other ICU medications include metoprolol, midazolam (Versed), and heparin sodium (prophylaxis). 

The patient's medical and family history remains unchanged from admission except

Summary:
The patient is a 40-year-old male with recent tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of acromegaly and B cell lymphoma, currently in the ICU after respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia in the setting of pneumonia and lactic acidosis. The patient's condition has been summarized as follows:

- The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with pressure support.
- He has a history of Bell's Palsy, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness.
- There is suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT.
- The patient's cardiovascular status is stable, with a heart rate in the 110s/120s.
- There are no signs of myocardial ischemia and frequent PVCs.
- The patient's renal function is normal, but close monitoring is required.
- The patient has a new diagnosis of acromegaly and further work-up is of no additional value during acute illness.
- Neurological examination is limited due to sedation, and MRI findings suggest possible masses in the spine.
- The patient is being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia with vancomycin and ceftriaxone.
- There is an increase in testicular swelling, which may be due to malignant infiltration.
- The patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.

Potential medical complications

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male with recent tumor lysis syndrome who is being worked up for new diagnoses of acromegaly and B cell lymphoma. The patient is currently in the ICU after experiencing respiratory distress and subsequent intubation.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 134 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 149/66 mmHg to 187/76 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 91%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 650 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. The respiratory system compliance and resistance index (RSBI) is 72.

The patient has a history of Bell's Palsy, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness. Imaging studies have revealed evidence of malignancy consistent with lymphangitic spread of a diffuse malignant process, thickening in the stomach, and ureters. A bone marrow biopsy showed inadequate samples due to necrosis but was suspicious for B cell lymphoma. The patient also has a new diagnosis of acromegaly.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of lactic acid, LDH, and several electrolyte imbalances. The patient is currently receiving various medications including antibiotics, sedatives, and

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 40-year-old male with a history of resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in the ICU after experiencing respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia. The patient initially presented with Bell's Palsy, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Impaired skin integrity
2. Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
3. Hypotension (not shock)
4. Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF)
5. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
6. Tachycardia, other

The patient has resolving tumor lysis syndrome, pneumonia, respiratory/lactic acidosis, and is being treated for presumed lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT. The patient is intubated, requiring high pressure but breathing spontaneously. The plan includes continuing ventilation and sedation, weaning pressure support as tolerated, daily chest X-ray, sending BAL cxs, continuing antibiotics, and monitoring ABG twice daily.

Cardiovascular: The patient is tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH is within normal limits, and TTE showed normal ejection fraction and no evidence of heart failure. Frequent PVCs were noted on EKGs, but no signs of myocardial ischemia. Metoprolol was switched to 50mg TID, and the patient will be followed up for other cardiology recommendations.

Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH, hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia consistent with tumor lysis syndrome. All trends have normalized now, and the patient has received two doses of rasburicase. CT shows evidence of malignancy consistent with lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in the stomach, ureters. Bone marrow biopsy was inadequate secondary to necrosis, although suspicious for B-cell lymphoma.

Renal/FEN: The patient's baseline creatinine has been present for several days. There is a Foley catheter in place, and the patient has not experienced urinary retention. The urine sodium of 23meq/L suggests the absence of marked hypovolemia. Monitoring BUN and Cr, no continuous IVF, bolus as needed, avoiding IV contrast, and nephrotoxic medications for now are part of the plan.

Endocrine: A new diagnosis of acromegaly has been made. Further work-up is of no additional value during the acute illness. Labs and confirmation of the diagnosis as well as additional imaging can be obtained when the patient is stabilized.

Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for possible masses; MRI head showed pituitary macroadenoma.

Summary:
The patient is a 40-year-old male with a history of resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in the ICU after respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. The patient initially presented with Bell's Palsy, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Impaired skin integrity
2. Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
3. Hypotension (not shock)
4. Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF)
5. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
6. Tachycardia, other

Plan:
- Continue ventilation and sedation with propofol/fentanyl/midazolam
- Wean pressure as tolerated but likely not much change until breathing trial tomorrow am
- Daily CXR
- Continue abx (4 more days) (vanco start [7-13], cefipine start [7-18]), start cipro
- Bronch today, send BAL cxs
- Continue ABG twice daily from art line or if changes in respiratory status
- ETT 6.6cm from carina by CXR today, RT will check and advance if necessary

Cardiovascular: Tachycardic

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new
   diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in ICU after
   respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive
   bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic
   acidosis. Original presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary
   retention, and lower extremity weakness.
   Currently trying to obtain tissue for definitive lymphoma diagnosis
   from BAL, peripheral blood, and paraspinal [**Hospital 7094**]: Intubated, one failed extubation on [**7-15**] secondary to
   copious secretions. Currently on pressure support, requiring high
   pressure but breathing spontaneously. Being treated for PNA; suspicion
   for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT.  CXR
   show worsening bibasilar infiltrates
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with propofol/fentanyl/midazolam
   -Wean pressure as tolerated but likely not much change until breathing
   trial tomorrow am
   -Daily CXR
   -Continue abx (4 more days) (vanco start [**7-13**], ceftazidime start [**7-18**]),
   start cipro today
   -consider Bronch today, send BAL cxs
   -Continue ABG twice daily from art line or if changes in respiratory
   status
   -ETT 6.6cm from carina by CXR today, RT will check and advance if
   necessary
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure. Repeat EKGs have showed frequent
   PVCs, no signs of myocardial ischemia.  Tachycardia is likely
   physiologic as patient has high metabolic demand secondary to
   infection, lymphoma, and high growth hormone
   -Switch metoprolol to 75mg TID.
   -f/u other cardiology recs if any.
   -transfuse if Hct<21
   -no IVF necessary now, bolus as needed
   .
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
   Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis although suspicious
   for B cell lymphoma.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
   -continue allopurinol
   -daily differential
   -repeat bone marrow bx this am
   -peripheral smear pending
   -f/u cytogenetics labs (Bcr-abl and FISH for 9,22 translocation)
   Renal/FEN: Cre at baseline for several days. Patient has Foley so h/o
   urinary retention has not been an issue. This will need to be monitored
   when Foley is eventually removed. UOP adequate at 29-90cc/hr. Urine Na
   of 23meq/L suggests absence of marked hypovolemia.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -no continuous IVF, bolus as needed.
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly. Per endocrine, further work-up
   is of no additional value during acute illness. Labs and confirmation
   of dx as well as additional imaging can be obtained when patient is
   stabilized.
   -f/u endocrine recs
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for
   possible masses; MRI head showed pituitary macroadenoma.
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial

s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc (since [**7-13**])

   -If patient does not recover, consider anaerobic coverage for possible
   aspiration PNA.
   -urine cx negative; sputum cx grew yeast; blood cx from [**7-13**] pending

   -HIV test when patient alert and able to consent
   -EBV IgM and PCR pending
   GU:  Tender scrotal swelling noted on admission and scrotal US

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of tobacco abuse, presenting with respiratory failure initially due to pneumonia. He was intubated and re-intubated for difficulty handling oral secretions. Currently, he has additional ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and diffuse bronchovascular disease with lymphangitic engorgement. The patient also has tachycardia consistent with sinus tachycardia with APCs and is on metoprolol. There is a suspicion of tumor lysis syndrome related to lymphoma, and the patient is on allopurinol. He has evidence of acromegaly with a pituitary adenoma and elevated HGH levels. The patient's bone marrow biopsy suggested lymphoma, and a repeat biopsy is pending. He has anemia, scrotal swelling, and a history of COPD. The patient's current medications include vancomycin, ceftazidime, ciprofloxacin, and bronchodilators. His vital signs include a temperature of 103.2°F, blood pressure ranging from 140/73 to 149/81 mmHg, heart rate of 126 bpm, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's lab results show leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, renal dysfunction, electrolyte imbalances, and elevated LDH levels

The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, fevers, and possible lymphoma. The patient has a history of tobacco abuse and enlarged lung fields. He has been intubated due to difficulty handling copious oral secretions and pneumonia. Empiric antimicrobials (Vanco, ceftriaxone) are being continued. A repeat bone marrow biopsy is suggested to confirm lymphoma. The patient also has sinus tachycardia with APCs, which will be managed with metoprolol. There are concerns about tumor lysis syndrome, acromegally, and anemia. The patient has multiple lines, including an arterial line and multi-lumen line. Prophylactic measures include DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP precautions.

Potential medical complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including copious oral secretions, pneumonia, diffuse bronchovascular disease, and possible underlying COPD. Complications may arise if the patient does not improve or if there are further infections.
2. Fever: The patient's fevers may indicate an underlying infection, such as pneumonia or lymphoma. Failure to identify and treat the cause of the fever can lead to worsening of the patient's condition.
3. Lymphoma: The patient has a suspected diagnosis of lymphoma, and complications may arise if the disease progresses or if treatment is ineffective.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure initially due to pneumonia. The patient was intubated and received mechanical ventilation. There have been recurrent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) episodes, and worsening bibasilar infiltrates are noted on chest X-ray. The patient also has tachycardia, possibly related to sinus tachycardia with atrial premature contractions (APCs), and is on metoprolol. Additionally, there is a suspicion of tumor lysis syndrome, likely related to lymphoma, and the patient is on allopurinol. The patient reportedly has acromegaly with evidence of a pituitary adenoma and elevated human growth hormone (HGH) levels. Further work-up and treatment for acromegaly are on hold. There is mention of scrotal swelling and a planned repeat ultrasound on Monday. The patient has anemia and requires follow-up. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's recurrent VAP episodes indicate a risk of ongoing respiratory failure due to pneumonia.
2. Tumor Lysis Syndrome: The suspicion of tumor lysis syndrome suggests a potential complication related to the underlying lymphoma.
3. Acromegaly: The presence of a pituitary adenoma and elevated HGH levels indicate the need for further evaluation and management of acromegaly.
4. Scrotal Swelling: The mention of scrotal swelling requires further investigation, which may reveal a potential underlying pathology.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia needs to be addressed to improve overall health and prevent further complications.
6. DVT Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving DVT prophylaxis due to the risk of deep vein thrombosis associated with prolonged immobility in the ICU.
7. Stress Ulcer Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal complications such as stress ulcers or gastritis.

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new
   diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in ICU after
   respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive
   bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic
   acidosis. Original presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary
   retention, and lower extremity weakness.
   Currently trying to obtain definitive diagnosis of lymphoma to start
   treatment.
   Respiratory failure: intubated, one failed extubation on [**7-15**] secondary
   to copious secretions. Currently on AC. Contributing factors to
   respiratory failure include PNA and suspicion for infiltrative
   malignant process on CT. CXR showing worsening bibasilar infiltrates
   over the weekend.
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with propofol/fentanyl/midazolam
   -Daily CXR
   -Continue abx, vanco (start [**7-13**]), ceftazidime (start [**7-18**]), cipro
   (start [**7-19**])
   -f/u BAL results and blood cx
   -ABG twice daily or if changes in respiratory status
   Tachycardia: Consistently tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed
   normal EF and no evidence of heart failure. Repeat EKGs have shown
   frequent PVCs, no signs of myocardial ischemia. Likely physiologic
   tachycardia secondary to infection, lymphoma, high [**Hospital1 **].
   -continue metoprolol 100mg TID
   -bolus IVF as needed
   Tumor lysis/lymphoma: : Labs at admission included significantly
   elevated LDH, hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia,
   hyperuricemia c/w tumor lysis syndrome. All trended down for several
   days until LDH bumped again startng [**7-17**]. s/p 2 doses rasburicase. CT
   shows diffuse evidence of malignancy - /w lymphangitic spread of
   diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters. First bone
   marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis although suspicious for
   B cell lymphoma.
   -f/u heme/onc recs
   -f/u results of second bone marrow bx
   -continue allopurinol
   -trend tumor lysis labs Q8H
   -daily differential
   -peripheral smear pending
   -f/u cytogenetics labs (Bcr-abl and FISH for 9,22 translocation)
   -HIV test when patient alert and able to consent
   -EBV IgM and PCR pending
   Anemia: Most likely secondary to bone marrow crowding from lymphoma.
   s/p 1 unit PRBCs on [**7-16**]
   -transfuse at Hct<21
   Acromegaly: New presumptive diagnosis based on clinical features.
   Definitive work-up postponed until patient can be stabilized.
   -f/u endocrine recs
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   ARF: Cre bumped early in admission from 0.6 baseline to peak 1.6.
   Trended down and now stable at 0.5. Thought to be secondary to ATN from
   tumor lysis with a possible contribution from presenting symptom of
   urinary retention.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -no continuous IVF, bolus as needed.
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now
   Orchitis:  Tender scrotal swelling on admission, scrotal US suggested
   epididymitis/orchitis. No clear masses. G&C swab negative. Exam
   starting [**7-17**] shows marked increase in testicular swelling, particularly
   on the left. Thought to be secondary to malignant infiltration and
   generalized edema.
   -f/u when patient stabilized
   -repeat testicular u/s if appearance worsens
   Distended abdomen: Increasing abdominal distention noted with
   hypoactive bowel sounds.
   -Colace, senna, dulcolax
   -Try to wean fentanyl as possible
   -guaiac stool
   Neurologic abnormalities: Initial patient complaints included R Bell
   palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of
   lower extremities. MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement of
   thoracic spine; MRI head showed pituitary macroadenoma.
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   Joint pain: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely
   secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.
   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake
   -continue pain control with fentanyl

Summary:
The patient is a 40-year-old male with a history of resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in the ICU after respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. The patient initially presented with Bell's Palsy, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness.

The patient has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, tachycardia, tumor lysis syndrome, anemia, acromegaly, acute renal failure (ARF), orchitis, distended abdomen, neurologic abnormalities, and joint pain.

Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and ventilated due to respiratory distress and worsening bibasilar infiltrates on CXR. Daily CXR and ABG twice daily or if changes in respiratory status are planned.

Tachycardia: The patient is consistently tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH levels are within normal range, and TTE showed normal EF with no evidence of heart failure. Frequent PVCs are noted on repeat EKGs without signs of myocardial ischemia. Physiologic tachycardia secondary to infection, lymphoma, and high [Hospital1] is suspected. Metoprolol 100mg TID is continued, and IVF as needed.

Tumor lysis/lymph

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 40-year-old male with a history of resolving tumor lysis syndrome, suspected lymphoma, and acromegaly. He is currently in the ICU due to respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia. The patient's presenting complaints include Bell's Palsy, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness. He is being worked up for new diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and has failed extubation once. He meets the definition of ARDS and is being ventilated at a lower tidal volume. Daily breathing trials are planned to work towards extubation.
2. Tachycardia: The patient is consistently tachycardic, likely due to infection, lymphoma, anemia, and high output state. Metoprolol has been started to manage the heart rate.
3. Tumor Lysis Syndrome: The patient has a history of tumor lysis syndrome, characterized by elevated LDH, hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia. Rasburicase has been administered, and tumor lysis labs are being trended daily.
4. Acromegaly: The patient presents with acromegalic features and a new presumptive diagnosis of acromegaly. Further work-up is needed to confirm the diagnosis.
5. Anemia: The patient is anemic most likely secondary to bone marrow crowding from lymphoma. He received one unit of PRBCs and will be transfused at Hct < 21.
6. Orchitis: The patient has tender scrotal swelling on admission, which is thought to be secondary to malignant infiltration and generalized edema. Further evaluation is needed, and a scrotal ultrasound showed epididymitis/orchitis.
7. Distended Abdomen: The patient has increasing abdominal distention with hypoactive bowel sounds. He is on bowel regimens and fentanyl weaning is being considered.
8. Neurologic Abnormalities: The patient has Bell's Palsy, loss of right facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of lower extremities, and pituitary macroadenoma. Neurosurgery consultation is pending, and MRI of the spine and pituitary are planned.
9. Joint Pain: The patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly. Pain control with fentanyl is ongoing.
10. Social Concerns: The patient's family is focused on the pituitary adenoma and further explanation of lymphoma concerns are warranted. A family meeting with onc and endocrine is scheduled to address these concerns.

Summary:
The patient is a 40-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress leading to intubation. He has a history of resolving tumor lysis syndrome, suspected lymphoma, and acromegaly. His presenting complaints include Bell's palsy, urinary retention, and lower extremity weakness. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, ceftazidime, and ciprofloxacin, for pneumonia. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and sedation with propofol/fentanyl/midazolam.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is due to pneumonia and a possible infiltrative malignant process. He requires continued ventilation and sedation. Daily chest X-rays will be performed to monitor his condition.
2. Tachycardia: The patient consistently has a heart rate in the 110s/120s. It is likely a physiologic tachycardia secondary to infection, lymphoma, and high hospital stress. Metoprolol 100mg TID will be continued, and IV fluids will be given as needed.
3. Tumor Lysis Syndrome/Lymphoma: The patient's initial labs showed elevated LDH, hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia, consistent with tumor lysis syndrome. LDH levels increased again, and the patient received two doses of rasburicase. A CT
